paragraphs: The inner courtyard of the magnificent baroque complex Invalidovna (House of Invalids) in the Prague district of Karlin will be transformed into a camp and military hospital for soldiers of the Napoleonic Wars for two days. French and Austrian soldiers will be sharing stories around the campfire, demonstrating their skills in handling weapons, military drills, and other abilities.
An unusual event with the speaking name "Soldiers in the Invalidovna 2025" will take place on September 19 and 20 (Friday and Saturday).
Anyone who wishes to can participate. Admission is free.
The organizer is the municipal district of Prague 8.

Guests will be able to learn about the daily life and service of soldiers in the Napoleonic army, see historical uniforms, muskets, other weapons and equipment, visit the camp and infirmary, and try dishes from French field cuisine.
An additional entertainment program will be prepared for the children.
In addition, as part of the organized tours, participants will be able to visit the interior of the House of the Disabled.
The number of seats is limited, tickets must be reserved in advance with the promotion coordinator at the entrance to the venue.

"You will be presented with a demonstration of uniforms and equipment, various displays, as well as lectures on the differences between armies, the life and routine of soldiers. Children will also find activities for themselves, as a creative workshop will be prepared for them."
You will be able to see voltigeurs of the 18th Line Infantry Regiment, the jÃ¤ger battalion K.k. JÃ¤ger-Bataillon, and soldiers of the renowned Imperial Guard.

"Also, there will be a chef working here from the era of the Napoleonic Wars, whose dishes will fill the entire courtyard with delicious aromas. Come to this unique event that will bring together enthusiasts and reenactors, well-known not only in our country but also abroad," the event announcement says.

Let's note that after the appearance of the Invalides in Paris, Emperor Charles VI ordered the construction of similar facilities in the largest cities of the Habsburg state. The Prague Invalides House was actively built in 1731-1737 and was intended to serve as a dormitory for 4000 people - war veterans with physical disabilities and their family members.

However, after the death of Charles VI in 1740, the construction was halted - only about a ninth of the original project was completed. Despite being an "unfinished construction," the complex today looks complete and is a protected cultural monument.
